text: Hello and welcome everyone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is October 12th, 2023, and we are in the final lecture, session six in physics is information processing with Chris Fields.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So Chris, thank you for this journey.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Exciting to get to this final lecture, which will be followed only by the last discussion for this go around.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's really awesome.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And to you for this lecture.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you, Daniel, and welcome everyone to this last session that I'll be doing with a focus on biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And just to give a brief review, as usual, we've focused in this course on generic quantum systems, by which I mean just any quantum system that has some number of degrees of freedom.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we really haven't made any assumptions about these systems other than the assumption that both interacting partners have sufficient degrees of freedom that they can be considered separable.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So their boundary is small with respect to the total size of each of the interacting systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I want to emphasize again that the approach we've taken is completely topological, so we haven't assumed anything about embedding in space.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And as we've characterized these systems, we focused really on two things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One, the amount of information that the two systems can exchange.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that amount is determined by the size of their boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's determined by this number N, which is the Hilbert space dimension of the boundary.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And as we've discussed now in several of the sessions, we can think of this boundary as a collection of N qubits via which the two systems A and B communicate.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The other feature of the interaction on which we focused
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is the reference frames that are used by the two systems to interact with this set of qubits.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it's these reference frames that assign the information that flows between A and B meaning or functional significance or actionability or however you want to refer to
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the idea that when a system gets some information, it does something useful with it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So those are very generic kinds of ways of characterizing an interaction.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You can think of it as a qualitative characterization, the semantics of the information, and a quantitative characterization, the amount of information.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But other than that, we've left the nature of these systems open.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this characterization allowed us to reformulate the free energy principle in quantum information theoretic terms as the principle that interacting systems behave in a way that will asymptotically align their reference frames.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we saw that
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: full alignment of reference frames is equivalent to entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the FEP drives systems toward entanglement, which is not surprising because that's what happens to generic quantum systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They may start out separable, but if they interact long enough, they'll become entangled.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we've had a discussion that is really very generic.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, we showed a couple of sessions ago that under these very generic assumptions, we got some interesting outcomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And one is that if systems have sufficient degrees of freedom, under the action of the FEP, they will be driven toward making
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: a diverse set of measurements of their environment because they're trying to get information about it so that they can predict what it's going to do.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that as they add ways of making measurements, they'll come up against non-commutativity of their measurements.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this may be due to intrinsic mathematical facts about their measurements, and it may just be due to their limited supply of free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So either way, what this induces is compartmentalization and the requirement for internal classical communication on internal boundaries.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I just wanted to reemphasize that this is a result of basic physics, and we see compartmentalization, of course, ubiquitously in biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But this suggests to us that features of biology that are very familiar actually follow from fairly deep physics, and compartmentalization is one of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We then talked last time about space and time and the computational requirements
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: on any system that is able to perceive an external clock or perceive an external spatial layout.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we discussed these from a very kind of developmental psychology point of view.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We discussed it using essentially the kinds of terms on the right here.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: as opposed to the kind of language that's much more technical and mathematical that's used in physics to derive spacetime as emergent from information transactions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But we at least hypothesize that both of these are ways of getting to the same sense of emergent spacetime.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And one important outcome of this discussion was that systems can perceive external clocks, so external periodic behavior, with fewer computational resources, so before they're able to perceive spatial layouts.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we'll get back to this later.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So organisms and maybe other complex systems seem to manage
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: a collection of capabilities that are all mutually dependent.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So memory depends on having layouts of persistent things that can be distinguished.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it depends on space, and it certainly depends on time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Space gives structure to persistent objects.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Memory allows you to identify persistent objects.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And objects, in turn, give structure to space by being located in different places.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And objects enable the fundamental requirement for memory, which is some form of error correction, so that one has enough redundancy
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: in the memory to check to see whether a memory has been degraded.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So organisms seem to manage a physically very important process, which is the use of space-time and memory as a basis for cognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You'll recognize these four functions that are mutually interdependent.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: as underlying complex cognition across the board.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And you can't really do complex cognition unless you have these capabilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So today we're going to put some of these things together in a discussion of biology and end by looking forward to future directions, not just in biology, but in all of quantum information theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So let's talk about biological systems, living systems, which of course includes us, but also includes all other organisms and communities of organisms and so forth at multiple scales.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I want to put forward a fairly radical hypothesis that living systems are just generic quantum systems
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: that the FEP has driven to a high level of computational complexity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So what does this really say?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It suggests that living systems are just quantum systems that have enough degrees of freedom and a sufficiently complicated internal dynamics
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: that the FEP, by requiring them to predict what their environment is going to do next, has driven them to make complicated measurements and complicated inferences on the basis of those measurements that enable fairly complicated actions on the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So these are systems that you would characterize as computers, essentially, information processing systems,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: with a high degree of computational capability.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now this is clearly as much a philosophical hypothesis as an empirical hypothesis, and that's due in part to the fact that we don't really have a good definition of what a living system is.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We can just point and say that's a living system and that thing over there isn't.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But beyond that, we don't have much of the theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And of course, people have worked on a theory of what is life for decades.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But there's not a lot of agreement.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so this is, in a sense, a definitional kind of hypothesis, and we test such kinds of hypotheses by seeing if they're useful conceptually to help us understand what living systems are doing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, as soon as we put forward something like this, inevitably the question comes up, are living systems really quantum systems, or are they classical in some intrinsic sense?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This question is really an artifact of two things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One, the continuing association between quantum systems and microscopic systems, which is, of course, traditional.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Quantum theory was developed to deal with microscopic phenomena.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It was first tested.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is the theory of microscopic phenomena.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it's only in the past couple of decades that quantum theory is being applied to big things, to cosmology, for example.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there's a long tradition of association between quantum and microscopic, and living systems are mesoscopic, much bigger than atoms, bigger than molecules.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, and they're not nearly as big as cosmological systems, so they're somewhere in between.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And those systems have traditionally been regarded as classical.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And even chemistry, even biochemistry is still taught in a very classical way.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we're not used to thinking of these things as quantum systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But at least in the approach we've taken in this course,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: All physical systems are quantum systems, and classical information exists only on boundaries, only on boundaries between systems, and it only describes their interaction.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I want to emphasize, I've said it before, but since this is the last class, I want to say it again, that this is not a universally held view.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's a view that's becoming more common, and I think a generation from now it will probably be the dominant view of things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But it's not fair to say that it's the dominant view now.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's, I think, quite fair to say that it's a view on the rise, especially in the quantum information and quantum gravity communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But from a strict empirical perspective, we know a number of things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know that accurate molecular dynamics calculations require quantum theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know that a lot of biologically important molecular processes use quantum coherence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know that things like hydrogen bonding can only be understood using quantum theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know that cellular free energy budgets are way too small to support fully classical information processing if we think of information processing in terms of what proteins are doing or what other molecules are doing in terms of changing shape.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know that shape changes in proteins and other molecules underlie all cellular information processing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if we think of them as actually implementing cellular information processing, we have way more information processing than could be funded classically.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And finally, we know that human cognition exhibits contextuality.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So human cognition uses quantum coherence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's not a classical causal process in all cases.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But this is still a very nascent field.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it's a field with a lot of potential.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I think, again, a generation from now, quantum biology is going to be regarded as a very mainstream endeavor, even though it's something of a small emerging field now.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I'll just show you one picture in support of this third point.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is a plot of measured free energy usage converted to numbers of bits processed at one kilohertz for a number of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, all that I could find a few years ago that had good caliometric measurements, versus the log of their area, their membrane surface area.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the thing to note here is that these cells are processing classical information at pretty low rates, kilohertz to gigahertz rates for a thousand bits at a time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we know that a lot more is happening in cells than that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Cells have many more than 1,000 proteins, and those proteins are all moving all the time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if that motion is processing information, then there's not nearly enough thermodynamic power to power all of that information processing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So let's now talk a little bit about life and living systems and what they look like.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Here's a view of living systems from the point of view of genome diversity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is a few years old, so it's out of date by now.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But it tells us a lot qualitatively.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It tells us that almost all genome diversity is microbial, that the sorts of organisms that we're familiar with, medium-sized organisms like us, animals and plants, have only a tiny amount of genome diversity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we think of ourselves as pretty diverse.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We think of ourselves as quite different from other animals, from flies or worms or
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: sponges or something like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But in fact, we're not all that different from them.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We share many, many proteins with all of those other organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We share the same cellular organization and so forth.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We're not, in fact, all that different from plants.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we're much more similar to the fungi than to the plants.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We get a very biased view of genome diversity when we just look at familiar large types of living systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Most genome diversity is buried down there in the microbial world.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This isn't the only way we can look at life as a diverse set of organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We can also look at it in terms of a cell lineage.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The fact that we're all related at the DNA level tells us that we're all descendants of a common ancestor, which is usually called LUCA, the last universal common ancestor.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And LUCA is generally modeled as being a cell, more or less like a bacterial cell, so fairly simple, with not very many pathways.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: with maybe a DNA genome.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if LUCA didn't have one, then they arose fairly shortly thereafter because all organisms that we know of have DNA genomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But the point of looking at life as a lineage is that we get a diagram that looks very much like the cell lineage
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: from an embryological situation, much like the cell lineage of our own body is growing from a fertilized egg.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in particular, looking at life as a lineage shows us that not only do we share DNA with all other organisms, we actually share a membrane, a cytoplasm that's continuous in time all the way back to Leuco.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and so continuous in time between us and bacteria.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you look at life this way, you realize that life is in a sense all one organism, all one connected structure that's developed over time through division, cell division.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so we're very closely related to all other parts of life in the same way that different cells in our bodies are closely related to each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The time spans just longer.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I mean, here the time spans three and a half or four billion years between us and Luca.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: These lineages have been diverging for that long, but they're still continuous.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in particular, they form a continuous cell membrane.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So when we think of life in this way, we realize that we're reasoning from just one example when we think about terrestrial life.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this strongly limits what we can say about living systems, what we can say about biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: that we really only have one example, the lineage that descends from LUCA here on Earth.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And at some point we may have more examples, and there's certainly groups working on artificial organisms that aren't part of this lineage, that are constructed from parts derived from this lineage, but aren't members of this lineage themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that may tell us something new about life.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But if we think of life this way, we see something very important, which is that as life grows, its boundary gets bigger.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And since the boundary of a system constitutes its informational environment, its dimension getting bigger,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: means that more information flows into it from its environment, and more information flows out of it into its environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So as life develops from LUCA, it gets a larger and larger informational environment, and this dimension of its boundary grows and grows.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now what that means, if you go back to our original picture of two interacting systems,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is that the number of the dimensionality of the physical environment is decreasing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we think of the physical environment as increasing in size.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have the expanding universe and all that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But what's increasing in size is space.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if space is emergent, then that increase is not a real increase in degrees of freedom.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What we're really interested in is
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the Hilbert space of the physical environment as distinct from the Hilbert space of life.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And as life gets bigger, it literally, quite literally, eats the physical environment and turns it into more life.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there's less physical environment around.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the trajectory of life is toward a bigger informational environment and a smaller physical environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And as the physical environment gets smaller, you might imagine it gets easier to predict.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And as the informational environment gets bigger, you have more information with which to predict the behavior of the physical environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this all hangs together very nicely with the free energy principle.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Here's another picture of this same thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If we start with some boundary here on the left labeled B around some system labeled S, and it's embedded in an environment E, then as S makes copies of itself through some process like cell division,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: then it starts to fill up more of E. It's actually converting degrees of freedom of E into degrees of freedom of its copies that it's made of itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if we think of some larger boundary drawn somewhere in E, here on the right side, I've labeled that B prime, what happens is that B prime gets slowly filled up with copies of S,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it starts to look like a large organism.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that's what life is doing in the physical environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's making a bigger boundary for itself at the expense of degrees of freedom of its physical environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we can ask, what drives this process?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Why is life doing this?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Why is it making copies of itself?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the answer to that question, at least one answer to that question, is the free energy principle drives it to do this.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I'll just show you some simulations from several years ago of a cell population in this upper left panel.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The green cells are stem cells that divide.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And they've been embedded in an environment that's safe on the left side and 100% lethal on the right side.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So they're embedded in an environment that's conducive to life on one side and very dangerous as you get toward the middle.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the purpose of these simulations was to study what happens
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When the stem cells are able to divide and create not just other stem cells, but create specialized progeny that don't divide, so somatic progeny that don't divide, and hence have free energy resources, thermodynamic resources, that they can devote to doing something other than dividing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Cell division is incredibly expensive when it comes to energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you take that energy and apply it not to cell division, but to protecting the stem cells, you can allow the stem cell population to expand.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that's what these other simulations show.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The blue cells are somatic cells that have very varying ability to protect the stem cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if they're fairly good at protection and they're fairly hard to kill down in the right bottom quadrant, you can actually get a population expanding well into the highly lethal part of the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this shows you the FEP in action.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What the stem cells are doing
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is constructing a very predictable neighborhood around themselves in the environment by dividing to make progeny that don't themselves divide, that just sit there and help protect the stem cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the stem cells are now living in a safer, more predictable environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that allows them to invade more and more of their physical environment by having this fairly benign informational environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this is the FEP in action, driving the expansion of life at the expense of the physical environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that lets us go back to this question that was raised last time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: about the mechanism of these scale transitions that we see ubiquitously in life.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Life gets bigger and bigger as time goes on phylogenetically and as time goes on developmentally.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We start with some molecular pathways that somehow get assembled into a cell.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That's the origin of life question.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: How does that happen?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And about 2 billion years later, cells start to group together to make multicellular organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, bacteria group together to make facultative multicellular systems like microbial maps 3 billion years ago, very, very early on.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But we don't see the emergence of obligate multicellulars until much, much later.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: before the Cambrian explosion, but still less than a billion years ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And from there, things get more complicated very quickly.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So one has large multicellular organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They develop complicated social relations that probably first emerged with social insects.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: but are certainly well developed in invertebrates, including in mammals.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Organisms group together in very complex ecosystems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And recall here that it's now known that all multicellular organisms have obligate microbial symbionts.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So all of our bodies are in fact very complex
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: ecosystems populated by many, many different species of bacteria.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that's true not just for us, but for trees and insects and worms and sponges and everything else.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So organisms from a body point of view are themselves ecosystems, and organisms organize themselves into ecosystems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And these ecosystems come into contact across the entire biosphere.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So processes as simple as the wind disperse organisms as small as bacteria all over the planet.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this scaling of life toward larger and larger organizational structures
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is in a sense the major thing for biology to explain.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the hypothesis that we floated last time was that this transition from very small scales to very large scales uses the same mechanism over and over again, or a mechanism that has the same structure over and over again.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the renormalization group is trivial, basically.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's just the identity operating at different scales, or mapping from one scale to the next.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the question is, can we approach this in any way?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Does this make sense?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And to try to make sense of it, we can go to the one real developed theory that we have in biology,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: which has been formulated by Dawkins and others as universal Darwinism.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is just kind of an abstraction of the modern synthesis between Darwinian evolution and genetics.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But universal Darwinism is incredibly simple and very obvious.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It says if you have systems and they can copy each other, they can copy themselves and the copies can diversify,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Then if you want to know what's going to happen at the population level, what you will find is the systems that copy themselves and diversify most efficiently will win because there'll be more of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So they end up dominating the population.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And winning gets called natural selection.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But natural selection is not an extra part of the Darwinian process.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's just the outcome of efficiency, of the systems that copy themselves most efficiently coming to dominate any population.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there's no sort of...
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: kind of hand of God or whatever reaching down and selecting some organisms and not others.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And of course, when Darwin put the idea of natural selection together, he was thinking very explicitly of the analogy of a gardener or a farmer selecting the crops or the animals or whatever that the gardener liked best and keeping those.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that's where this selection metaphor comes from.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But there's no real process of selection in evolution by natural selection.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's just copying and diversifying.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But this clearly is just the outline of what a real mechanistic theory would be, because we need to have a story about what copying is and what diversifying is,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and what efficiently means.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in particular, to address the question that we raised a couple of slides ago, we need to know whether these mechanisms are the same or at least isomorphic of the same form at different scales.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's what I want to talk about for the next little bit.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Let's start with copying.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Up until the 70s, copying in biology really meant DNA replication and, to some extent, cell division.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But the focus in evolutionary theory was on DNA replication.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in the 70s, it was realized that whole genes could be duplicated, so whole genes could be copied.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then shortly after that, it was realized that particularly in prokaryotes, where functionally related genes are next to each other in chromosomes often,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: in what are called operons, that operons could be duplicated, and so entire pathways could be duplicated.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And as genomes began to be sequenced and structures of genomes were understood, it became clear that genomes could be copied.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And of course, we have two copies in each of our cells, with the exception of red blood cells, of our complete genome.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But some plants, for example, have six or eight or even more copies of their genome in each of their cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there's large-scale genome duplication.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Cell division is clonal duplication of cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Organismal reproduction works by cell division in all known systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: colonies or societies of organisms reproduce themselves, in part through cultural transmission, and entire niches reproduce themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, in processes like forest evolution or desertification or even urbanization, we see humans reproducing the same sorts of niches in city after city, for example.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So these forms of copying have the kind of hierarchical dependencies that one might expect.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So to duplicate pathways, you have to duplicate genes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: To duplicate cells, you have to duplicate the genome.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: To duplicate organisms, you have to duplicate cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this suggests that this copying operation
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is indeed scale-free, that each level, the copying operation at each level enables the copying operation at the next level.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, with diversification, we see much the same thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In the early days of the modern synthesis and still in the work of people like Richard Dawkins,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: diversification is is generally thought of as random so mutation for example is thought of as random and um here i have barbara mcclintock who is kind of the hero of non-randomness in doggedly over decades pointing out that much of genome diversification is not random at all and um
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: that genomes actively diversify by moving whole clusters of genes around and duplicating them or just changing their positions so that they're under the influence of different local control.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So at the gene and genome level, you have active diversification by various processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: enzymatic processes, as McClintock showed us, transposon-mediated mechanisms, which are enzymatic at the bottom.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Cells actively diversify by lots of different mechanisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in the 70s, Carl Woese was, in part, personally responsible for pointing out that
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In the microbial world, there's a lot of horizontal gene transfer.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And again, no one believed him for quite a while.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But now it's broadly accepted that microbes exchange DNA very frequently and across large distances phylogenetically.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is how things like microbial resistance to antibiotics spread so quickly, or one way that it spreads so quickly.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it's a tremendous agent of essentially speciation, to the extent that that even makes any sense in the microbial world.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Of course, in our cells, we have functional differentiation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: As mentioned earlier, there are lots of symbiotic interactions that lead to diversification in cells by radically altering their local environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And of course, sex is a mechanism for diversification.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Organisms actively diversify in many different ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The most obvious one is just by moving around, by moving to a different environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the organism is exposed to different inputs and is allowed different outputs.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so it can move into a different direction, morphologically, genetically, etc.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Organisms can regulate their own evolvability by altering things like DNA repair systems or activating transposons.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Again, these are sorts of things that...
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: went very much against the grain when they were first discovered, but are now pretty well accepted.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And of course, organisms can learn and so can diversify their behavior by diversifying their computational capabilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And social groups, of course, actively diversify in many different ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And organisms are increasingly, non-human organisms are increasingly regarded as having cultures that they pass on intergenerationally by intergenerational learning and can exchange with other groups.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So diversification is active.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and occurs at every scale.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And again, diversity, although this is a bit less clear than in the case of copying, diversification mechanisms at one scale enable diversification mechanisms at other scales.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, for example, transposon-mediated mechanisms enable horizontal gene transfer in microorganisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the FEP tells us that efficiency is actually about intelligence because the FEP drives systems to build good models of their environments or the behavior of their environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And what a good model lets a system do is reach a single goal by many different means because it allows, in a sense, planning.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and it allows flexibility and adaptability.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I put William James here on this slide because he was the first, as far as I know, to define intelligence as this ability to use different means to reach the same goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, in evolution, that's long been known, and it's called convergent evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When you see two lineages adapting to a single environment,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: with very different genetics and very different morphologies.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And often the organisms will end up with similar morphologies that work well in that environment, but very different genetics and very different biochemistry.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So throughout evolution, we see this phenomenon of functional convergence
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: balancing structural divergence at many, many different levels.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we have multiple genes for very similar proteins.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have multiple pathways that do more or less the same thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have different cell types that support the same basic functions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have tissues that are fairly different, but that have the same functions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, eyes and different kinds of organisms that allow vision, but have very different structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And of course, we have functional convergence and social relations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if we look at how cells interact, traditional evolutionary theory really focuses on competition.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We now know that cells cooperate, that they exchange resources in various ways, even across vast differences in phylogeny.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, the interchange between plants and fungi, or between bacteria and us.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know that cells, in a sense, persuade each other by secreting things like hormones that cause other cells to do different things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Cells deceive each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, microbes that are trying to escape the immune system.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And cells coerce each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Cells even kill each other when they detect, for example, genetic defects.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So these sorts of social and economic and even political ideas are useful for describing living systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: from the level of cells on up.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I mean, they were developed in social settings to describe what goes on in human societies and then extended to other animals.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And now it's very clear that they extend to individual cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So when we think about social intelligence, we can think about social intelligence even at the level of individual cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we see these sorts of competition, cooperation, resource exchange, et cetera, even at the level of microbial mass, so biological structures that are 3 billion years old.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, of course, intelligence is necessary, but it's not sufficient for being selected.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It won't protect you from impacts of asteroids that happen to land on your planet.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: which has happened often in the evolution of the Earth, and we're now trying to figure out how to predict and prevent such things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But it's, you know, who knows whether we'll be successful at that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But this intelligence
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is necessary when it's viewed in this FEP sort of way.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Intelligence is what lets you build models that enable you to predict the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So where does this leave us?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: By thinking of evolutionary theory in terms of scale-free mechanisms, we seem to have a picture
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: in which we start with quantum systems with a certain level of complexity, and the FEP actually gives us scale-free biology or something very close to scale-free biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that's very interesting because the FEP, of course, is a generic principle.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It just says that systems do what they need to do to keep existing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this way of thinking gives us some predictions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One is that we'll find compartmentalized problem solving everywhere because the FEP drives compartmentalization.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the reason is just non-commutativity of measurement processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It predicts that we'll see hierarchical organization everywhere, in the same way we did on that first compartmentalization slide, where once you have a number of compartments, you need a metacompartment that, if nothing else, distributes free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So some sort of very basic attention system.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we see attention systems, of course, throughout biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It predicts that living systems will have very limited classical data structures.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So since they have to write classical data on their boundaries, and their boundaries are much smaller than they are, then they'll, and because writing classical data is expensive, living systems will tend to use as little classical data as they can get away with.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Since classical data is needed for
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: thermodynamic irreversibility.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Where we see thermodynamic irreversibility, that's where we look for classical data.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We saw that organisms will be able to detect time first before they can detect space.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we can expect organisms to have clocks even before they can represent space.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And of course, we see things like diurnal variation throughout biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And finally, the FEP predicts this asymptotic collapse of separability back to entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it predicts that living systems will eventually degrade and become indistinguishable from their environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we know that happens at the cell level and the individual organism level.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We call it death.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The FEP seems to give us a lot of the features of biology, and it gives us these features in a scale-free way, and it derives them from this very basic physics.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So where does that leave us?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I think it leaves us here with a challenge, not just to thinking about the FEP, which is what this course has been about,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: but to quantum information theory in general.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And that challenge is to evolve from the kind of conceptual and theoretical utility that we've been discussing in this course, and which is very well developed in the physics community, to some sorts of empirical and technological utility
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I've listed three areas here where QIT is very active.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One in quantum gravity and cosmology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And you're probably familiar with things like string theory that sort of fairly famously seem not to be empirically testable.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the quantum gravity community is enormous.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Many thousands of people working in this area
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But coming up with theories that can be tested empirically at the scales that we can actually do experiments, so at accessible energy scales, for example, has proved to be very difficult.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this is a real challenge to the field, is somehow getting not just to empirical testability, but to some sort of technological utility.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And you can imagine that if the main prediction of
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: quantum gravity is that space-time is emergent, that there could be enormous utility in that, some ability to manipulate the way space-time emerges.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The second area, of course, is quantum information and computing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And here, massive resources are being put into technological utility.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I think it's reasonable to expect that we'll have useful quantum computers within a generation at any rate.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there I think the field is going quite well.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the last area of what we've talked about here is quantum biochemistry and biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this, I think, is an area with enormous promise that maybe some of you will actually contribute to.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: making this area more useful technologically and more accessible empirically.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But at least we have a picture of how these different areas fit together.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Thank you very much for participating in this class.
speaker: SPEAKER_01
